caption: Table 1: #unique for ensembles. We report the #unique on OOD datasets (see §4.1 for the datasets). The ensemble size M is 5 for all methods; it is the max possible #unique value.
description: This table presents the number of unique predictions (#unique) made by different ensemble methods on in-distribution (IN-Val) and various out-of-distribution (OOD) datasets.  The ensemble size (M) is consistently 5 across all methods, representing the maximum possible number of unique predictions. The results show the diversity of predictions achieved by each method, highlighting the superior diversity of the proposed SED-A2D approach compared to baselines like Deep Ensemble and variations using hyperparameter diversification or Naive A2D/DivDis.

caption: Table 2: OOD generalization of ensembles. Models are trained on the ImageNet training split.  M is the ensemble size. For Naive DivDis and A2D, we use the ImageNet-R as the OOD datasets where the respective diversification objectives are applied.
description: This table presents the out-of-distribution (OOD) generalization performance of different ensemble methods on various datasets (ImageNet-A, ImageNet-R, C-1, C-5). It compares the performance of single models, deep ensembles, ensembles with diverse hyperparameters, naive DivDis, naive A2D, and the proposed SED-A2D method, using three different aggregation strategies: oracle selection, prediction ensemble, and uniform soup. The table shows that the proposed SED-A2D method consistently achieves superior performance across all datasets and aggregation strategies, particularly for larger ensemble sizes (M=50).

caption: Table 3: OOD detection via ensembles. For each OOD dataset (C-1, C-5, iNat, and OI), the ensembles are tasked to detect the respective OOD samples among ID samples (ImageNet validation split). We show the AUROC scores for the OOD detection task. Ensemble size is fixed at M = 5.
description: This table presents the Area Under the Receiver Operating Characteristic curve (AUROC) scores for out-of-distribution (OOD) detection using different ensemble methods.  The AUROC is a measure of the effectiveness of each method in distinguishing between in-distribution (ID) and OOD samples.  The table compares the performance of several methods, including a single model, deep ensembles with and without hyperparameter diversification, naive versions of Agree to Disagree (A2D) and DivDis, and the proposed Scalable Ensemble Diversification (SED)-A2D method.  Two different uncertainty estimation methods (Bayesian Model Averaging (BMA) and Predictive Diversity Score (PDS)) are used. The results show that the SED-A2D method, particularly when using the PDS score, provides superior OOD detection performance across various datasets.
